member.name: T:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx
member.summary: The win multimedia timer is erratic. Using a one msec tick (fastest), the measured interval is +-100 us. Also note that it takes about 10 ticks to settle down after start. This component attempts to reduce the error by running at one msec and managing the requested periods manually. This is accomplished by using a Stopwatch to actually measure the elapsed time rather than trust the mm timer period. It seems to be an improvement.

member.name: T:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx.TimeProc
member.summary: Client callback occurs when the time period has elapsed.

member.name: F:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx.TimerInstance.period
member.summary: The requested time between events in msec.

member.name: F:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx.TimerInstance.elapsed
member.summary: Actual accumulated msec since last event.

member.name: P:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx.Running
member.summary: Indicates whether or not the timer is running.

member.name: F:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx._timers
member.summary: All the timer instances. Key is id.

member.name: F:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx._timerID
member.summary: Multimedia timer identifier. -1 is not inited, 0 is fail to init, other is valid id.

member.name: F:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx._timeProc
member.summary: Called by Windows when a mm timer event occurs.

member.name: M:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx.NativeMethods.timeSetEvent(System.Int32,System.Int32,Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx.NativeMethods.TimeProc,System.IntPtr,System.Int32)
member.param: Event delay, in milliseconds.If this value is not in the range of the minimum and maximum event delays supported by the timer, the function returns an error.

Resolution of the timer event, in milliseconds. The resolution increases with smaller values; a resolution of 0 indicates periodic events should occur with the greatest possible accuracy. To reduce system overhead, however, you should use the maximum value appropriate for your application.
Pointer to a callback function that is called once upon expiration of a single event or periodically upon expiration of periodic events.

member.name: T:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx.NativeMethods.TimeProc
member.summary: Called by Windows when a mm timer event occurs.

member.name: T:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx.NativeMethods.TimerCaps
member.summary: Represents information about the multimedia timer capabilities.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Timer class. OK to throw in here.

member.name: M:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx.Finalize
member.summary: Override finalizer only if 'Dispose(bool disposing)' has code to free unmanaged resources.

member.name: M:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx.SetTimer(System.Int32,Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx.TimeProc)
member.summary: Add or update a timer instance.

member.name: M:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx.Start
member.summary: Starts the periodic timer. OK to throw in here.

member.name: M:Ephemera.NBagOfTricks.MmTimerEx.MmTimerCallback(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: System multimedia timer callback. Don't trust the accuracy of the mm timer so measure actual using a stopwatch.
member.param: The identifier of the timer. The identifier is returned by the timeSetEvent function.
The value that was specified for the dwUser parameter of the timeSetEvent function.
